THE GREATEST care should be taken in what we eat and drink, yet we are too often indifferent and careless, notwithstanding health depends on what we eat and drink.

In regard to drink nothing but the best should be taken. It costs no more than the indifferent quality, if people would only ask for what they know is the best Old Scotch Whisky is the most wholesome beverage yet known Mackie's Scotch Whisky gives an undoubted guarantee to those who are not judges of quality.
CITY ANALYSTS LABORATORY,
138 BATH STREET,
GLASC0W, 8th October, 1906.

I hereby certify that I have taken samples of every vatting of Mackie's White Horse Celler Blend of Scotch Whisky used in bottling during the month of September, and the results of my analyses indicate that it conforms to the standard for Pot Still Scotch Whisky set up in the London case. I am also of opinion that it is an old Whisky of excellent quality and flavour, which has been well matured in wood.
JOHN CLARK, Ph.D., F.C.S., F.I.C.,

div.head: THE EGYPT EXPLORATION FUND.
div.p: The lecture which Professor Naville deli- vered on Monday evening last week at King's Collage on hia fourteen yesre' work on the exploration of the great Hathor temples at Deir-el-Bahari was, ays ^fr. W. St Chad Boa- eawen in the "Globe," an add res" of great importance, not only on aocount of the ur- oheologial matter, bat alao on aooount of the statements he made at the oloee as to the future plans of the Egyptian Exploration Fund. In his diaoourse the laturer txaoed the progress of the work from the first om- it in 1898 to ita condition in 1907, and as the various stages of work were explained and the progress made illustrated by beautiful photographs, it was made clear what a great work had been* accomplished. When Mariette gave up his work none of the greattemple was clear except the forecourt. The remain* of the colonnade*, the shrine", and the great alter were all hidden beneath tons of débris and landslips from the great western mountain. In addition, the remains of a Coptic monastery and village filled the portions above gronnd. This applied to die great temple built for Hatsbepsn by the architect SenrouL The very existence of the older temple of the eleventh dynasty built by Mentuhetep, and the shrine* of the Hathor Cow, one of the moat important discoveries ever made, on which Professor Nnville waxed justly eloquent, wae quite unsnspected. The work of the daring of the old temple belongs to years ago, in the present rapid progress of events ; but there was ODe spécial point of interest which the lecturer referred to, and which was oertainly new. In the forecoort at the top of. the camp lading np from the plain was discovered an immense aquare altar, approached by steps. As the Egyptians did not use burnt offering", its use was obscure, but Professor Naville show- ed that it resembled the great altars shown in the sculptures of Ankh-en Aten, at Tel-el- Amarna-whioh were piled with flowers, fruits, and various offerings of braad-caka and other objects what time the King amended to offer his prayer to the noonday sun. When conclud- ing his remarks on the exploration) of the eighteenth dynasty temple, the lecturer showed a photograph of the absolutely cleared and partially., restored building, and remarked, "that it was now in a muoh better condition than it had ever been sinoe the latter days of ths Egyptian Empire." Por he said the Egyp- tians seldom or ever repaired a building, and more frequently when in partial deoay it be- oamea quarry for the workmen of later. times. This had oertainly been the fate- of the older temple which preoeded the building of the great queen. This work bad oooupied ten years. Passing now to the work on the older temple, buried benrath mounds of débris only partially natural, the lecturer brought out many most important points hitherto un- known, and especially interested his audience by exhibiting photographs of many of the sculptures retained at Cairo. Among these were a beautifnl painted portrait group of Mentuhetep and hia negro queen. There i" also another interesting group of one of the queens sated on a throne and receiving offerings of milk and aka from attendants, while two waiting maids plait her hair and put the hairpins in it ; certainly the earliest picture of an early breakfast The king, Profes- sor Naville said, was a polygamist, two wives being priestess" of Hathor, and they were buried in tombe in a courtyard behind the pyramid and bautifolly deoorated shrines erected in the oolonnade above the tombs. The lecturer showed photographs of the very beau tiful sarcophagus of Prinoea or Queen Kareit now at Cairo. Professor Naville devoted much time to the account of the discovery of the perfect shrine of the goddess Hathor, under the form of -a cow- which has been so often described. He mentions that careful rosoaich had shown that there was a distinct association between the Hathor cow and the Apis bnIL He bad said that the peculiar markings on the body of the cow were not stars, as at first sup- posed, but laves of a "four - leafed clover." Ia tliis anotheqgroof of the antiquity of the sham- rock t The most important point in the lecture was Professor Naville's exposition of the ques- tions of the King's tomb. He showed mo*t clearly that tho great vaulted puisage extending fivod hundred fat into the mountain could not be the tomb ; but ratiier that great alabaster shrine, with its red granite roof, was. the chamber of the Ca, or doublo of the king, which was worshipped by the later kings ITsertesen, Amenophis II., aud others. He then prooeedod to show that there was much evidence to identify tho tomb with that found in the south-west corner of the oourt by Lord Dufferin in 1889, which Dr. Naville cleared again, and in which le found a large uninscribed sarcophagus. In the oouree of the lecture, Pro- fessor Naville referred to the great help be had received from Mr. Hall, of the British Museum, aud Mr. Aryton. The most important statement of all came at the conclusion of this interesting lecture. Mr. Naville, in peaking of the future work of the Egypt Exploration Fund, said that it was feared that the intended exavations at Abydo* would have to be given up this season. Tho work on Deir-el-Bahari had oat so many thousands of pounds that unless subscriptions were forthcoming, a season's rest would be necessary. Surely there must be many wbo, while unable to visit Nile land, have had its beet art and literature brought to them year after year by the Fund, who would contribute their guinea, or as much more as they like, in order that thia should be remedied, and the twenty-five years work be continued.

div.head: A Faithless Husband
div.p: A-Cairo Bey, rich anil well known in the district, two years ago married an Israelite dancer named Latifa,and handsomely furnished for her a flat at Daher. Uuliappily the fickle iinturo of the Bey was not proof against the blandishments of other artistes and his infi- delity was the cause of many domestic squab- bles. These only served to exasperate the husband with the result that, he completely deserted the home. On Monday morning, ac- iunqianieiTby a servant and several porters, he went to the house, and expressed his intention f taking away the household goods. This procedure the wife energetically opposed, and her cries soon brought several Israelites on the x-ene. One, a certain Leon Sion, interfered and a sharp combat followed, during which l/pon Sion sUbbed the servant with a knife. Meanwhile Mahmoud,fouml means of informing the police, who, after considerable difficulty stopped the fray, and arrested Leon Sion, consigning him to the French Consulate, and transporting the wounded servant to the hospital, wherq he lies in a grave condition.

div.head: GENEVA AS A RESORT
div.p: THE KHEDIVES VISIT

A^oorres pondent writes from Geneva onder dite'of the Slat nit The Khedive is here in Genevajtod goes daily in hinnotor-car to the "Parc de* Eaux Vives" to luncheon. His Highness is looking very well and apparently enjoying the change. The weather is very finejnst now and Geneva as charming as ever. The Parc des Eaux Vives is only a quarter of an hour's walk along the shore of Lake Leinan, and is the fashiouable resort daily during the aummer for visitors to Geneva. The grounds are magnificent and the speci- mens of trees from different parts of the world to say nothing of the assortment of beautiful flowers and plants, are an endlçss source of enjoyment to all Jo vers of nature. 'lucre is k first class restaurant with an excellent cuisine. Tea and coffee are served at smnll tables in the park under the shelter of the frees. A fine orchestra plays daily and just now there is an open air theAtre with performances every afternoon anil evening, and plenty of scope for sport of all kinds.

div.head: TRADE OF ALEXANDRIA
div.p: CONSULAR RREPORT

According to the report on the' trade and commerce of Alexandria for the year 1906 by Mr. Greig, Acting Vice-Consul, whjch was presented to the Houses of Parliamnnt last week the total tonnage of ships which entered the Port of Alexandria during the year 1906 was 3,695,829 tons. In 1903 the total tonnage was 3,591,281. The increase during the jiast year, therefore, amounts to. 104,548 tons. Great as the increase is, it falls short of the average yearly increase of the five preoedfrig yearn, which was 243,132 tons. The tonnageofBritish, French and Italian shipping has decreased in almost identical proportion* to the total ton- nage of each, whereas Greek, German, Belgian, Austro-Hungarian, Danish and Ottoman shipping have increased in varying degreen. British shipping claims 1,473,087 tone, or 40 per cent of the total amount, and more than the Ottoman, Anstro-Hungarian, Italian and French shipping combined. , There has, nevertheless, been a decrease in British shipping of 48,792 tons as compared with the year 1905, whereas the average year- ly increase during the five preceding years w"s 99,809 tons. Ottoman shipping, as in 1905, occupies the second place with 344,238 tons, or abont 9 per cent of the shipping of the port, representing an increase of 4,003 tons' during the year. The average yearly in- crease during the five preceding years was 32,868 tons. Austro-Hungarian shipping, which occupied the fifth place in 1905, has risen above France and Italy to the third place with a total of 325,549 tons, or 9 per cent of the tonnage of the port, and has rea- lised an increase of 14,881 tons, the average yearly increase 'for the five preceding year* having been 12,357 tons. Italian shipping, which occupied the third place lost year, now stands fourth, having yielded a place to Austria Hungary, with 323,942 tons, or 9 per cent of the shipping of the port, hut has sustained a decrease of 8,342 tons. French shipping, which bold the fourth place in 1905, having likewise beeu passed by Anstrio-Huiigary, now stands fifth with 316,500 tons, or 9 per cent of the port, ami has sustained a decreaso of 9,629 tons as compared with 1906, the average yoarly in- crease during the five preceding years liaving Itoeu 6,697 tons. Genn shipping holds the sixth place with 296,647 tons, or 8 per cent, of the total tonnage of the port aa compared with 7percent forl905and4 percent forl904.There has been an increase daring the past year of 34,976 tons, the average yearly increase during the five preceding yearshaving been 40,442 tons. Greek shipping h-s risen from the eighth to the seventh place with a tonnage of 241,290 tons,oi6 percent of the tonnage of the port, as compared with 6 per cent for 1908, 4 per cent, for 1904, 3 per cent for 1908 and 2 percent in 1902. It has shown the consider- able increase of 68,229 tons during tho year, tho average yearly increase during the five years preceding having been 18,510 ton*. Russian shipping occupies the eighth place with 176,819 tons, or 5 per cent bf the total shipping of the port. Belgian shipping has risen from the tenth to the ninth place with 63,628 tons, or 2 per cent of the tonnage of tho port as compared with 1 per cent, in 1905. It ha" increased by the considerable amount of 29,*267 tons during the past year, the aver- age yoarly increase for the five preceding years having been 2,083 tons. Danish ship- ping occupies the tenth place with 86,785 tons, as compared with 10,996 tons in 1"00 and 23,052 tons in 1905. It has increa- sed by 12,733 tons during the post year. Swedish and Norwegian shipping accounted for 32,736 and 25,871 tons, respectively. Their tonnage united'fall slightly short of their combined tonnage for 1905 Dutch ship- ping claims 15,634 tons, or 2,772 tons, more than in 1905. Roumanian shipping, unrepresented in.1905, contributed 12,811 tons. This i* due to the service organised by the Rouinainian Maritime Company betwéen Constant and Uiis port. Cyprus lias during the past year been oon nected with Alexandria by a regular weekly mail service organised by the Limassol Steam- ship Company. A British maritime enterprise of the near future will be the sorvico of the Egyptian Mail Steamship Company between Marseilles and Alexandria A Fronoh company, too, is said to be studying the question bf a sorvice from Dunkerque to Alexandria, touching possibly at Havre, Tangier, Oran, Algiers and Tonis.

div.head: EGYPT IN PARLIAMENT.
div.p: COLLAPSE OF HOUSES.

The following question* concerning Egypt were anked and answered in the House of Common* on the 1st inst:- - Mr. John Robertson.- To ask the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs whether he can obtain an official statement' of the number of buildings which have*bollapeed in Alexandria, Cairo and their environ* within the last twelve months and the number of persona who have been thereby killed or iqjored. Sir E Grey.- I will enquire whether it is possible to obtain such a statement
CAIRO WATER SUPPLY.

Mr. John Robertson. - To ask the Secretary of 8tate for Foreign Affairs whether in view of the fact that a number of honse* in Cairo, near the Boghoa Paaha bridge, are without water "apply, and that the Cairo Water Company, though repeatedly appealed to by theproprietora to meet their needs, has done nothing, he will suggest to the Egyptian Government the expe diency of acting on the long-standing demand for the establishment of a Cairo mnnioipality which oan meet the requirements of the city. Sir E Grey. - I have no information on the particular point of the water supply and the contract with the Water Company. The question of the Municipality is a large and eomplioated one, with which I am not prepared to deal at present.
THE EDUCATON BUDGET

div.head: AT THE ASSUAN DAM.
A WONDERFUL TRANSFORMATION.
div.p: Writing on the 19th inst. a.correspondent of "Pall Mall Gazette" says :- After an absence of quite eighteen months, I find myself again at Assuan, and, perforce, I have paid a visit to the Dam. I was exceedingly surprised at the transformation achieved on the west side of that marvellous structure. There is, as before^ very little to interest the eye on the drive out, which takée about thirty minutes from the time of leaving the hotel. The way leads across the sandy expanse which, broken here and tliere by overpower- ingly high mosacs of sandstone and granite, causes the casual observer to imagine be ia traversing the soene of aonio prehistoric vol- canic upheaval Bat oq a closer observation one sees in the formation and lay of tho rocks that the right bank was in reality in former times the bed of a river, fpnning, in all pro. bability, an outlet or tributary to the great inland sea, which is said by ihe geologists to have existed in the Sahara D esert At the reservoir there is quit* a little colony. Where, a little over a year ago, only a relentless stretch of sand existed, there appear now numbers of neat and cool-looking buildings, standing in their own grounds, which are developing into produoe-bearing and shade-providing gardens, affording a restful spot on which the eye, tired with the glare of the sun and the surrounding desert, can repose.. These houses are the residences of the offioials attachod to the Dam, and of the engineers engaged on the new works. I entered one of them, and found it delightfully cool and com- fortable, fitted with electric light and various conveniences with which the ordinary resident has to dispense. Some of the houses are excellently situated, standing at the summit of a series of terraces covered witJi the green plant, which out here cakes the place of tnrf. All this shows the riohness of Egypt's soi!, and proves that with care and attention even the sand can be inado fruitful. I do not mean that fhe sand alone can be transformed. What I intend to convey is the fact that with modem appliances and careful supervision no spot in Egypt need lie bàfréh. At present it is rather " critical tiino in Assuan from a hygienic point of viow. It is the period of tho green water, a stretch of water computed to be 500 miles in length, and con- taining a fungus whose colour gives the name to tho water. This piece of water takes from seven to fourteen days to pass Assuan, aud daring tliat timo it ia extremely dangerous to drink the water, OH it brings on fever and colic. The smell is also most offensive. The residents at the Dam get the frill benefit of this water, if one may call it benefit, and at present they do not feel over happy at their lot Butin time all this will be a tiling of the past, and I feel quite loth to leave what appears to be, and certainly is, a delighful spot to reside in

div.head: CASINO SAN STEFANO.
div.p: Les fêtes se suivent au Casino San Stefano ; e'est ainsi qne samedi soir aura lieu le grand bal avec " Cotillon ", offert par la direction k ses abonnis, qui ne manquera certes pas d'être des plus animés. Dana le concert vocal et instrumentai d'au- jourd'hui nous anronB le plaisir d'entendre Carmen pour Baryton, Fédora pour Ténor et Gioconda poor Soprano. Mo Braoalenous prépare un programme des plus choisi*, pour dimanche prochain.

div.head: THE GRANT TO LORD CROMER
div.p: SPEECHES IN PARLIAMENT
A CHORUS OF PRAISE

As announoed in onr oable of the 81st ult the Royal Message recommending the grant of £50,000 to the . Earl of Cromer for his great servioee to Egypt waa diaoaued in both boasee of Parliament on Tuesday week. In the House of Lords, the Marqness of Ripon, (Lord Privy Seal).in moving that their lordships concur with the Commons in making the grant, said :- It ie with great personal gratification that I rise to perform the doty which falls to my lot on this occasion. Lord Cromer's great services are ao well known to yonr lordships and to his countrymen, that it would be ont of place, and almost waste of time, if I were to go through any lengthy description of them now. The great success of Lord Cromer's administration in Egypt has afforded justification for the belief that Englishmen are eminently qualified for the administration of affaira in any part of the world, and on behalf of any nation. During the 24 years in which my noble friend has been at the head of Egyptian administration, be has done a work of infinite difficulty and of the highest importance-a work beneficial to the people of that country, bringing order out of chaos and laying firm aud solid the foundation of a pros- perity calculated to confer much honour npon the British name. To most of ns here, and to many outside the Honse, Lord Cromer's name is chiefly connected with the great work which be has done in Egypt, but it would be a great mistake to suppose that his servioes bave been entirely confined to that country Lord Cromer was trained in a good school of administration. He was private secretary to my noble friend the late Lord Northbrook, and I Jiad the advantage of having Lord Cromer as a finan- cial member of the Indian Council during the chief part of the time that I had the honour to fill the office of Viceroy of India, I waa able then to wsteh, from day to day, Mb devotion to doty, hia firm grasp of financial principles, and his high administrative ability. It ia, therefore, with no hesitation that I submit to. yod a resolution, and aakrou to express to the Sovereign your readinem'to concur doing an honoor to one who has renderiAsrvice* alike to the Crown and the this country (hear. hear). A recognition snch as that which it is intend- ed to be offered to Lord Cromer has very generally been confined to members of the naval and military servioes, bat I rejoice that npon this occasion, 'we are about to concur in conferring a similar hononr npon one whose services have been of a civil nature. I think that we shall do well if we do not hesitate to place Lord Cromer in the same position and on perfect equality with the eminent soldiers and sailors who have been honoured iu this way, I therefore beg to.move :- '"^hat an humble address of concurrence and thanks be addressed to his Majesty in answer to his most gracious message" (cheers). The Marquess of lansdowne.-We, on this side of the House, do not yield to noble lords opposite in onr appreciation of Lord Cromer's services, and we desire to associate ourselves with all that has been said by the noble marquess, and to accept onr full share of res- ponsibility for the proposal which the Govern- ment has made. Lord Cromer has, indeed, conferred signal services upon this country, and upon the Empire. I was glad that the noble marquess reminded us tliat, although we dre apt to connect Lord Cromer's name almost exclusively with Egypt, it was not in Egypt alone that Lord Cromer did good work for his country. 1 can well remember the réputation which Lord Cromer left behind him in India as fi- nancial member of the Council but it ia upon Egypt that Lord Cromer lias left an indelible mark, and it is tho affairs of Egypt which have ennhled him to write a page in the history ol this country which is all his own. On snch an occasion as this one is apt to look for a parallel, but 1 really believe there is no case which stands exactly on all fours with that-.of Lord Çroiner. Our position in Egypt is an altogether exceptional position, and Lord Cromer's position in that oountry was also exceptional. I think that it would be almost trae to say of him that during his long term of office lie was able to serve two masters with equal fidelity and success. Of British interests he was a watchful custodian. Nobody need be'reininded of the nature of British interests in Egypt It is due to Lord Cromer that our position in that oountry, at one time undefined, and, indeed, somewhat precarious, became assured and consolidated.

div.head: MARVELLOUS ACHIEVEMENT IN EGYPT.
div.p: But if Iiord Cromer wa* the foithfol gnardii an ot British interests he was not a less faith; fnl guardian of the interests of the oountry committed to his charge. Nothing oould have been more whole hearted than his devotion to Egyptian interest*, and hia work, when one oomee to review it, was, indeed, a marvellous achievement in the intere*t* of Egypt We *ee how, under hia guidance, the great natural resources of that oountry were developed, and when we consider the manner in which he wa* able place its finances upon a sound footing ; when we remember how every branch pf Egyp- tian administration has, daring hi"" triture of office, been put upon a sounder footing, we may indeed claim for him that, under the geidanoe of no other man, could *o much have been done for the people of Egypt I daresay many of your lordships may have, from time to time, perused those admirable reports- whieh every year Lord Cromer was in the habit of aub-withoot feeing that this oountry flllgtM i be prond that we had such a men to Lord Cromer to represent n* in other porta ot the world. But although the publie generally has been well aware of the magnitude of Lord Cromer1" achievements, although it has, an to apeak, seen the great output of work of which he wee the author, it waa reserved for tboee behind the scenes, who know the conditions under which that work was performed, tokbowin the face of what great difficulties, in tbefhoe of what apparently insuperable obstacles that task was so admirably accomplished. Lord Cromer had to oontsod with many disappoint- ments ; he had to overcome many rivalries, but be triumphed over them ail, hem am he possessed in thé highest degree two great qualities indispensable in a public mao-the qualities of tact and tenacity. It would be un- just to Lord Cromer if I did not refer to my conviction that the satisfactory understanding obtained by the late Government with Prance iu regard to many outstanding question^ and notably with regard to Egyptian affaira, would not have been obtainable, or, at all events, attainable upon so satisfactory a basis, if it had not been for the exceptional position which Lord Cromer occupied among the repre- sentatives of the other Great Power* in Egypt In this House, at any rate, I am aura that no diaoordant note will be raised whan we con- sider the proposal laid before us by the noMe Marquees (hear, bear). .i. 1 We feel that this proposed grant ie no exoreeive reward for those great public ser- vices, and we trust that it may enahia Lord Cromer to enjoy the well earned rest which we hope he will take after the laboura which it is well known have involved every serious strain upon his health. We trust that he may live long to see others carry out the great work which will always be associated with his name (cheers). The motion was then agreed to.

div.head: IN THE COMMONS.
PREMIER'S WARM TRIBUTE.
div.p: There was a very large attendance when the Premier, Sir Henry Campbell BanDerman, open- ed the debate in the House of Hëbeaid :- Hitherto snch grants have, with exceptions, been oonfined to those who bare performed conspicuous service to the coun- try in war, but I do not imagine that in this House of Commons there will be many who wsuld wish.to exclude from tangible acknowledgment the quieter and less resound- ing, but not less useful or lees deserv- ing servioes of pacific administration (bear bear). It would not be too muoh to any that of all our pacific administrators through- out the Empire of the preeent. day, Lord Cromer is the foremost ' man-foremost in oourage, wisdom, resource, and pattern", pnd foremost, too, by the splendid résulte he has obtained (liear, hear). It is not in Egypt only that he has done great service. Before his career there commenced be had done work in India the effect of which is felt to this day. We all know how. Lord Cromer's administration of the affaira of Egypt has been marked by striking material progress, but his oountrymen are even proud er of the security and liberty which his labour secured-of the revival of jostioe and work he did for education. When we reflect that 24 years ago, when he began this task, Egypt was bankrupt, and almost effa- ced under the burden of taxation and in- debtedness, and that all his efforts for .re- form had to be carried out under a system surely ' the most grievous to be borne that ever hampered an administrator, it is diffi- cult to find words in which to express the admiration we Jpel for hia steadfastness and courage.

div.head: REGENERATION OF EGYPT
div.p: Lord Cromer belongs to the school that holds it wise to hasten slowly if superimposing the civilisation of one race npon another. He pro- foundly disbelieved in any attempt lo force the Egyptiou people into Western mould. If lie had cared to ilaczle the world with swift and sensational results, there were plenty, of capitalists ready to go up end develop Egypt on the lines of European finance, and Lord Cromer would have saved himself infinite trouble if he had accepted their assistsnoe and yielded to pressure and let them in. Bot be saw that the regeneration of Egypt oould ohly be effected through the Egyptians themselves, and in devising meeeuras for the emapeipatiea of the peasantry from the bondage of debt and preserving them in their holdings, he laid (he foundation of aa agrarian policy which ia the foundation of the future Egypt That policy, entitles him to the gratitdda of the country be has served so well, and to the admiration and ol his countrymen. In losing him we lose a public servant who in all the anxious and harassing events and complications associated with Egypt bee been a tower of strength, and whose oourage, resource and wisdom, and loyalty have never tailed. Now that he hsscome home brokeuia health, liaving spent hia strength and hie fortune in the public service (hear, hear), I believe that, m showing him this mark of esteem, we shall not only be honouring a great man who -baa greatly served hie oeuutry, hut we shall he enabling the oountry and the Empire thresh this Hones, to raoogniaa, aa they desire, "re- debt they owe to Lord Cromer (cheers).

div.head: MR. BALFOUR'S TESTIMONY
div.p: oonaistekt with tht honour of the country and with .the tradition" of the House (cheers). ThU i* tha firat titeo, so far as I know, that the Houw of Commons has been asked to vote to a civü servant any .great mark of national giwtitade: But Lord Cromer belongs to a diff- erent class from that of other civil servants, however distinguished their services. We Imve before us in Egypt the fruits of the work of one great men. It stands out as isolated and sin- gular a work of genius as the more sudden glories of some great military triumph, and, is separated from the ordinary work of even the greatest of the great race of oivil servants abroad who have done such inestimable ser- vice to the British Empire by special char ao tens tics which mark it off and render it matter for differential treatment (cheers). Within a quarter of.a century Lord Cro- mer has raised Egypt from the lowest pitch of social and economic degradation until it now stands among Oriental nations, I believe, absolutely alone in ita prosperity. Everything he has touched he has succeeded in. Every cause he has taken in hand he lias furthered. He leaves Egypt able to look back open an administration longer, more beneficent, qpd more fruitful than, perhaps, can be boasted by any one of those great predecessors who have csrrie*I out great civilising work among races who have not risen to the level of-those whose lot it has been to govern them.'The difficulty of governing races in these conditions is great, and ["quires sympathy, courage, and stead- fastness. Lord Cromer has all these qualities. He has dealt successfully with diplomatic and social difficulties in a manner which has earned the permanent gratitude of the Egyptian people, and which is well deserving of some distinguished mark of the gratitnde which fin" House and the country owe to one of the greatest of their servants (cheers).

div.head: THE HOME PRESS ON THE GRANT.
div.p: The press at home is unnniinoua in approv- ing the grant to-the Earl of Cromer, and refers in glowing terms to his splendid work in Egypt We append a few excerpts : "Tun"1' We have lavished rewards upon tho sailors and the soldiers who have led our fleets and our armies to victory, but no exact precedent hu been found for the acknowledgment, hy a grant of public moneys, of such inestimable services to England as Lord Cromer has ren- dered her. The grant to Sir Rowland Hill was the nearest case which could be discovered, but the resemblancebetween the circumstance-! in which it*was made and those of the present vote is not very close. Lord Ripon said that, had no precedent existed, he should have l"een glad to create one, and, in effect, that is what the Government have doue. We congratu- late them upon their action and upon its exceptional timeliness. It is meet and wise that à nation such as ours should pay homage to splendid achievements in other fields than in the field of war. They demand gifts not less rare, labours as arduous and more prolonged, and courage equally high. At a time when the mind of the whole world is. lient on furthering the cause of peace, it is particularly becoming that the nation which has so often proclaimed its teal for that cause should bestow a signal mark of ifs favour upon à statesman whose life work lias been a work of peace. Iiord Lansdowne, who followed the leader of the House, called to mind tho difficulties and the obstacles under which that work was ac- complished. The greatness of the felicitations of the whole world. Lord Cromer's charactei lie* in this, that, whatever secret cares and anxieties they laid upon him, he never suffered them to divert his course from the goal he liad set himself to reach. It has been his happiness to reach that goal amidst the felicitations of the whole world. It remained for his Sovereign and his countrymen to confer upon him a material token of tlie deep appreciation they entertain of |iia achievements, and they have discharged this duty to themselfes and to him by the vote of last night. The work, which Lord Cromer lias done is there for all the world to see ; all the world -has looked u|ion it, and lias declared with one accord that it is good.
"DAILY TELEGRAPH"

There have been few periods within the last thirty years at-which Lord Cromer could not have honourably enriched himself hy quitting -the responsible post in the occupation of which ha did such invaluable work, both for the Empire iyid for the people of Egypt. As a reward.for his great services the sum of fifty thousand pounds is but paltry, though it is understood that it represents the maximum the great Proconsul would accept Lord Cromer will value far more than this provision for his rehrementthe tributes paid to hisaebievements by the representatives of both the great parties in the Btate, who alone could appreciate them at their full value. It was a happy incident that the two leaders in the House of Lonls, Lord Ripon and Lord Lansdownes, should liavebecn in a position-to bear testimony to Lord Cromer's work in India, before he had been transferred to the fuel in which he won hisproudest laurels.
"TRIBUNE

In conferring a signal honour upon Lord Cromer Parliament has been truly repre senùtive of a grateful uation. The system of presenting'testimonials upon their retirement to men who have done good work and earned general esteem has, perhaps, shown signs of brief rather overdone in many minor spheres ol BririrhMe ; H may have become a little too like a matter of course that the dock or the servioe of plate or pnrso- shall be the natural sequel of a long spell of parish work or the smoothly suooeesful discharge of business duties. Bat it h not so at the top, in tlie big affairs of the Empire. There the grant is a rare event, reserved for extraordinary services. Lord CYoneriaonaofthemyfew who have had the opportunity to do oonspicuouily extraordinary work on the peaceful side, and of the still fewer who have surpassed all ex- pectations and confounded all apparent probabilities by the manner in which such opportunity ha" been grasped. He has done not a little for the peaco of the whole world, sinoe, as was well said last night, his Egyptian career undoubtedly helped to make possible the cleaning of the slate as between England and Franoe, and warm ^friendship now established.
"DAILY CHRONICLE"

Lord Cromer's powers of mind and character were singularly adapted to the conditions in which Egypt stood for many years after ho took office. If the conditions have changed, the change is chiefly doe to his own high ser- vice"", and it would be absurdly unfair to make light of what he has done because the prosper- ity which he .has produced may call for an advance in the methods of government.
"DAILY NEWS"

Among all tho great servants of the Empire, Lord Croinet holds a very special position, lie has by universal admission achieved successes which twenty three years ago would have seemed impossible. lie has extricated the. finances of tlie State from the confusion and lespnir in which -lie found them. He has rescued tho peasants from oppression end overwhelming taxation. He Iras introduced order and justice into public life. He has worked wonders In engineering and irrigation. Not least pf his claims to public gratitude is tlie strong hand with which he has defended Egypt from the private avarice and the finan- cial conspiracies which have made up so much of tho history of Imperialism elsewhere. Such a career stands out conspicuously in tho ad- ministrative successes of a nation that ii not poor in the records of honest and public-spirited government

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: Après une ouverture ferme, le march*) a un peu réàctionné pour reprendre en fin de séance et clôturer sensiblement nu môme niveau qu'hier. Comme d'habitude les affaires ont été en général elairsemées. 'Devant l'impuissance des haussiers h déterminer une hausse rapide et suivie, il faut bien reconnaître que les ven- deurs existent mais que, retenus par l'espé- rance de plus hauts prix en présence du mon vomont actuel, ils attendent une accentuation de la reprise pour se défaire de leur stock à des conditions moins désavantageuses. (/qel- qnes acheteurs se présentent occasionnelle mont, et c'est là toute ^'explication d'une corbeille en apjiarenee Imimnière mais tpii n'achète que fort peu. En ce qui concerne l'allure dés valeurs égyptiennes sur les marchés européens elle ert moins bonne, sans compter que le taux d'es- compte hausse encore de 1/8 à 3 7/8. Cela n'a d'ailleurs que médiocrement im- pressionné notre place, puisque l'Agricole s'a- vance de 8 1/8 vendeurs à 8 1/8 acheteurs et la National Bank de 20 à 20 1/4 vendeurs. Il est vrai que la Delta Light et la Daïra Sanieli restent stationnaires aux cours res- pectifs dé 9 7/8 et de 12 7/8 et que l'Obli- gation Crédit Foncier rénetionne môme de 303 à 300 vendeurs l'ancienne et de 261 K 258 vendeur" la nouvelle. lies Lots Turcs bénéficient de 2 fr. h 164. ainsi que la Cassa di Sconto. à 40, les Nnngo vich Hotels de 1/4 delivre à 13 1/2, l'Urbaine de 1/16 à 3 11 IG, ainsi que l'Union Foncière à 4 6/8 et l'Alexandria Water à 11 1/2. En baisse, au contraire, les Bières d'Ale xandtie et du Caire, les premières de 175 à 160 les Privilégiées et de 90 à 87 les Dividendes, les secondes de 90 à 87 les Privilégiées et de 37 à 35 les Dividendes, la Banque d'Athènes "le 111.1/2 à 111, la Deferred Delta de 9 1 /2 à 9, la Building Lauds de 2 5,'I6 à 2 1/4, le Banco di Roma de 105 à 104, la Banque d'O- rient "te 118 1/2 à 118. Tandis que les Privilégiées Tramways per dent 1 fr. à 141 1/2, les Dividendes gagnent 2 fri à 302. En sens inverse, la part de fondateur Comptoir penl 1/16 à 2 15/16, pendant qne l'action ancienne gagne 5/32 à 2 31/32 et la nouvelle 1/8 à 2 7/8.. Parmi les petites valeurs, la Sait and Soda progresse de 17/9 k 18'3, la Delta bind de 1 13/16 i 1 15/16, les Estates de 11/16 à 3/4 acheteurs, la Port Saul Sait de 14 à 14/3 et la fondateur United de 2 A 2 1/4 acheteurs, tan- dis qne l'Ordinary Khédivial Mail fléchit "le 21/9 à 21/6, l'Aboukir de 29 à 29 vendeurs et les Riu de 3/4 A 11/16. Le Comité do l'Association des courtiers en valours d'Aloxnndrie avise les agents qui n'ont pas encore encaissé le montant leur revenant du fait des coinjietwatiniis des transactions sur les actions de la Bourse add Banking "l'avoir à ilouer sans retard au Clearing pour onoaisser lo montant de leur créance. A I Assemblée des ageuts de change du Caire, tenue avant-hier, il a été unanimement décidé de rétablir en principe le marché A terme. Les membres de l'association se sont réunis de nouvoau hier soir pour fixer les non dirions de détail.

div.head: THE COTTON MARKET
div.p: KEARSLEY AND CUNNINGHAM'S WEEKLY REPORT

LIVERPOOL, August 1. The demaud ou the Spot for Egyptian continues very quiet, but prices keep fairly steady and quntfftiom are uuoliunged on the week. ^ In Futures a small business has resulted ; the following are tlie latest quotation* :- Aug. 10.43 Nov. 10:41 Fob. 10.31 Sep. 10.45 Dec. 10.35 .Mar. 10 31 Oct 10.43 Jau. 10.32 American Futures. The Market this week has again boon very quiet in tone, with only a very limited business doing outside of tho professional trading. There have been frequent moderate fluctuations anil to-day's prices are 7^ @ 8 points higher for the Current, month and Augiist(Septemher delivery, and 8J @ 4 points higher for the other positions, than those of last Thu relay. The slight improvement is more due to a certain sensitive- ness about the real condition of tJiKCrop, because more or less tlie weather has continued dry with high temperatures. There is not apparently so far any serious anxiety, but there is anxiety of a kind. We are also awaiting with considerable interest the Bureau report to be issued in New York to-morrow after our market is closed, and as Liverpool does not reopen until Tuestlay tho 6th insti, there is a genera 1 squaring up of accounts. Tho latest values are, delivery :- Aug. 6.89 Nov./Dro. 6.551 M*r./ApL 6.6S Aug./Sep. 6.77 Dec./Jan 6.54J Aprit/May 0.56 Hept./Oct. 6.64 .lan./Feb. 6SXJ May/.Iune 9.67 Oct/Nov. 6.581 FeU/Mar. 6.51

div.head: TELEGRAMS
THE CASABLANCA TROUBLE
FRANCES NOTE TO THE POWERS
FRENCH LEGION EN ROUTE
div.p: Paris August 7

The representatives of France have notified the various powers who signed the Aot of Alp's iras, -of the growing necessity of organis- ing the police in the Morocco ports, affirming that France is resolutely determined to main- tain the authority of the Sultan, and the integrity of tho nmpire, to assure of commercial transactions, the punishment of the authors of tlm massacres, and the organisation of the Casablanca police in accordance with Spain. (llavat
Paris, August 7

The' cruisers "Gloire," "Coude," "Jeanne il Arc," and "Gueydon" and two companies of the Foreign Legion have left Oran for Casa- blanca. The French representatives have handed to the signatories of the Act of Algeciraa a declar- ation declaring that events in Morocco had uiitstripi>ed the contemplated measures, and rentlinuing the intention of France to maintain the authority of the Sultan and the indépen- dance of Morocco. Casablanca would be policed in conjunction with Spain. (Reuter)
TANGIES, August 7

It appears that the "Galilée" landed GO bluejackets at the request of the Consul and in concurrence with the Bashaw. They were proceeding to the Consulate when they were tired upon by Moors whom they repulsed with the Imyonet. The "Galilée" and "Du t'hayla" then bombarded the Moorish quarter ami tribesmen on the beach with melinite. (Reuter)

div.head: TROOPS OCCUPY BELFAST.
div.p: BELFAST, August 7

The city was occupied by troops this morn iug. Strong patrols were posted. Companies of the 4th Middlesex, Sussex, and Essex Regi meats were subsequently marched to their positions watched by hundreds of citizens. (R)

div.head: THE HAGUE CONFERENCE
THE HAGUE, August 7
div.p: It is understood that Great Britain has agreed to withdraw the urgency clause from the limitation of nimaments proposal, merely declaring the examination of the question as highly desirable. (Reuter)

div.head: NEW GOVERNOR OF AZER BAIJAN.
TEHERAN, August 7
div.p: Prince Fermai) Pinna lias been appointed Governor of Azer Bnijnn and has been hastily .'eut to Tabriz owing to the Turkish incursion. (Reuter)

div.head: THE RUSSIAN NAVY.
ST. PETERSBURG, August 7
div.p: The Government has decided to lay down during 1907 ? two battleships of a new type, evolved by the Ministry of Marine, of 19,970 tons, armed with tenl2 iuoh guns and fitted with turbine engines ; their speed will be 21 knots. (Reuter)

div.head: THE SWINEMUNDE MEETING.
BERLIN, August 7
div.p: The .Tsar anaEmperor William exchanged toasts at a farewell luneheon on board the "Standard.'' The Emperor said that he hoped the Tzar would be permitted to accomplish the construction of his fleet.(Reuter)

div.head: TELEGRAMS.
EVICTED TENANTS BILL.
div.p: House of Lords. The Evicted Tenants Bill has passed the second reading. Lord Lans- downe strongly criticised the. measure but dijf not advise' its rejection, ithioh, he said, would increase the difficulties of the Irish executive. Moroovor the bill had been support- ed by enormous majorities in the House of Commons.

div.head: THE NAVAL MANGEUVERS
div.p: During night matuouvres off Portland the "Quail" and "Attentive" collided. The "Quail'' was badly (lamageff in the bows and has been placed in dock for repairs. (Reuter)

div.head: COWES REGATTA.
div.p: Lord Dunraven's "Kariad" won the Emperor William's Cup at Cowes. (Reuter) The "Meteor" has won the King's Cup at Cowes.(Reuter)

div.head: HOME CRICKET
div.p: Derbyshire boat Hampshire by an innings and 93 runs. Yorkshire boat Lancashire by 9 wickets. Leicestershire beat Northamptonshire by one wicket Middlesex beat Somerset by an innings and 176 runs. Gloucester beat Essex by 197 runs. South Africans boat All Ireland by 151 runs. The following matches have been drawn Kent v. Sussex ; Notts v. Surrey and Warwickshire v. Worcestershire. (Reuter)

div.head: SLEEPING SICKNESS EXPEDITION.
SUCCESSFUL EXPERIMENTS ON CATTLE.
div.p: The president of the Liverpool School of Tropical Medicine, Sir Alfred Jones, has received the following telegram Irotn the sleep itig sickness expedition of the school, which was sent to Africa early in May last "Send quantity atoxyl immediately. Cattle experi mente indicate success. Montgomery Try- panosomiasis Expedition, Broken Hill, N.W. Rhodesia." Atoxyl is the name of tho remedy recommended fqi therapeutical treatment in cases of sleeping sickness. The sleeping sick- ness expedition nrrivod at Kolotno on June 10, where they wore the guests of Mr. Codrington, the Administrator, who gavo every facility for their work. At tho end of the present month it is intended that Dr. Kinghorn, one of the members of the expedition, shall proceed direct to Fort Jameson. Mr. Montgomery, the other member, will go west to the River Kafne, and up that river towards the Congo. He will then strike across the country, and meet Dr. King- horn on the river Luapaln about November, traversing the whole of tho time a territory infested by the T'se T'se fly. One of the main objects of the expedition, which is financed by the Liverpool School and supported by the British protectorates concerned and tho British South African Company, is to endeavour to prevent the spread of sleeping sickness into districts hitherto uninfested. The expedition will also study tho disease on the spot, and will pay special attention to the disease of animals and tho distribution of biting flies. It is the fourth expedition of the Liverpool School that has been sent to Africa to study try- panosomiasis.

div.head: MONEY AND SHARE MARKET
div.p: (From our financial correspondent)
The Money Market

It is stated on very good authority that the Egyptian Government has this week been a heavy seller of Consols, the object being to strengthen the position of the National Bank. This is a commendable pwlicy, and satisfactory as showing that the banka are beginning early to make preparatives for obtaining gold at the lowest possible prioe, in order to bo ready for the heavy autumn demand incidental to the moving of the coming ootton crop. It is impossible to entimate at the present moment the probable requirements for this purpose, but all the imports from the ootton fields foreshadow a splendid crop, so that the total imports of gold will necessarily amount to f. large figure, as we have said before, we have no doubt that all the necessary accommo- dation will be obtained without seribns incon- venience to the money market Several causes have contributed to the heavy Call in the reserve reported this week, tbedhirf of these being demands for cash in eonnection with the holidays and end of month require- ments. The imports of gold from abroad amounted to £259,000, but £862,000 in ooin and £572,000 in notes went into circulation, with the result that The reserve shows a decline of £1,181,667, at £24,867,412. This compares with last year's total of £24,629,000. The proportion to liabilities is g per oent lower on the week at 46] per cent, the proportion at this period last year being 47.41 per oent The discount market is firm, and three months'bills were yesterday quoted 8, 11/16 to 3] per cent In consequence of a large ordet from ths Continent, the price of bar gold lias risen Jd. to 77/10}.
Silver
During the greater part of the week the silver market remained quiet, but strong buying yesterday sent the price up to 32, 1/16, the highest figure touched for five months.
The Stock Market

Business on the Stock Exchange has be- come so scarce of late that many members concluded this week that their time would be much more profitably spent on the moor or by the sea, and the consequenoe has been that during the past two or three days the "House" has had a somewhat de- serted^ appearance. Idleness has prevailed in most sections, and the tone lias been any- thing but/satisfactory. It is gratifying to note, however that the Egyptian section lias been firm and that an appreciable amount of investment buying has been going on. This bears out what we said last week, tliat the leading bro- kers are taking an optimistic view of the trade troubles connected with the .crisis. The announcement that the assets of Messrs Salmi Brothers were considerably in excess of the liabilities has had a reassuring effect, and it is believed that in the case of Messrs Harriraan Brothers, whose creditors moet next Wednesday the liabilities will not prove to be heavy. Consols continue the most surprising feature ol markets, and it is quite within the bounds of possibility that before the next settlement they will lie down to 80. Large quantities of tho stock were delivered at the settlement this week, and heavy buying on behalf of the Government lias totally failed to assist the market.
Consols

The premier security on Monday declined to 82], the lowest price touched for over half a century. On Tuesday and Wednesday the market was firmer, but yesterday there was a further loss of |, the closing quotations being 82ft for cash and 82, 18/16 for the account To-day Consols have improved 1/16 for the account
Foreign Bonds

In the international market, the feature has been the weakness of the older Japanese issues. A further decline of J yesterday put the 4} per cents, down to 93} and 89] respectively, while the Pours were quoted 89. * Russians have also been sold, and the Fives relapsed to 83}, the Fours being down to 78]. To-day Japanese have been irregular the new Fours have shed }, but two other issues are J better.
Home Ralls

The home railway market lias been very flat, and prices have given way heavily in spite of good traffics and excellent holiday prospects. The labour agitation is exercising a depressing effect, as investors refuse to have anything to do with these shares in tho present state of unrest The directors of the railways are adopting a firm attitude, which if pursued must result in the employes moderating their demands. The possibility of a strike Is remote, as the railwaymens' union represents only a small section of the total employes. The Scotch shares Beem to be the only steady points. Yesterday Caledonian Pre- ference advanced Î, and North British Pre- ference }, but moet of the heavies declined } to 1. w
Americans.

Shares in the American railway section have moved rather irregularly, Wall Street having been pessimistic regarding the future outlook. Yesterday the market here was affected by uncertainty over the Pacific dividend!, and during the morning there was considerable selling of the leading shares Later the tone became firmer. In the "Street" it was an- nounced that the Southern Pacific dividend had been declared at the rate of 6 per cent as against the previous distribution of 5 per cent, but that no action has been taken with regard to tbs Union Pacific dividend. The news seemed to have been fully discoanted. Southern Pacific fell to 90], closing at 91], while Unions left off at 145], alter being 145}. The tone in Americana has been better to- day. Unions have advanced }.
Egyptians

Daring the greater part of the week prices in the Egyptian market have been good, and there has been a fairly general advanoe all- round. The tone eased off a little yesterday, but this is explained by the sparsity of bus- iness. National Bank have been up to 201, closing tonight 19]-}, and Agricultural Bank, after beiug 8}, close 8 1/16 8/16, but these prioes are well up on balance. Daira Sanieh, which have been fairly largely dealt in, were quoted yesterday ex dividend, the Ordinary being 12} - 18] ex 25/-"., and the Deferred 65- 70 ex £10. Delta Land & Investment after changing bauds at 2, are easiet at 1} offered, but Egypt- ian Estates are firmer since the meeting at ]-} Salt and Soda and Egyptian Markets have been scaroely mentioned, closing unchanged at 13/16 and 1 ] respectively. Union Foncier close 4} -}, and Khédivial Mail Ordinary are much letter at 22/6-23/6. United Egyptian I^nds are firmer at 3/8 - } and Corporation of Westen Egypt are steady at 7/16-9/16. Anglrt-Egyptian Bank are still dull at 12] - }, but Land Banks are firm at 7-}.
Mining.

Liquidation from Paris has caused mining shares to be dull, and the market has also suffered, in common with other sections, from lack of business. De Beers were down to 22], a fall on the day of 5/16, while Premier were no better than 9 8/8, at which they showed a loss of }. Modderfontein gave way } to 4], and Tanganyika 3/16 to 4, 7/16. To-day mines have been idle Egyptian Mining shares are unmontioned, and prices show practically no cliange on the week. . The closing prion to-night in a. follow. :

div.head: A Dramatic Event
Popular Actress cured by Dr. Williams Pink Pills.
The Victim of Nerve Troubles, Indigestion and Languor- all other Medicines had proved Useless
div.p: Incidents in the careers of well-known people are of special interest to the publje ; reoognising this a representative waited upon Miss Amy Corallie at the Métropole Theatre, Birmingham, to gather some details of her career. Miss Corallie - in private life Mrs. Finlay- is twenty-four, and has been before the foot- lights since childhood. "Yes, 1 can spare a few minutes," she said ; "time enough to tell of the good I derived from Dr. Williams' Pink Pills for Pale People. "I have had the honour of appearing before Royalty, and the late j. L. Toole often com- plimented me upon my stage work ; yet for a long time 1 was acting under a positive prose cation. Sharp pains in my back dragged me down ; sometimes I went to the theatre feeling more dead than alive, with scarcely enough strength to drag one leg after the other. My blood felt chilled ; rheumatic pains flew all over me, and my limbs became almost useless. "1 struggled against these ailments, but it was of little use. My face grew pallid, and I felt entirely worn out, yet all night long I scarcely closed my eyes in sleep. 1 lost all vitality, and felt depressed and weary, while my memory failed. Pood upset rue, and I always had a nasty taste in my mouth. "Friends noticed the change in me, for at the least exertion I gasped for breatli, and my heart throbbed. Often I have returned to the dressing room fainting and exhausted. Every noise got on my nerves, and made me tremble from head to foot. * "I took so many medicines that my digestion was quite upset. Then fortunately 1 accepted the advice of a friend, and tried Dr. Williams' Pink Pills. Relief followed, and so I continued with these pilla Then I improved rapidly, and soon could enjoy meals without being tormented by indigestion. "My blood was nourished, and a healthy colour returned. I felt more energetic in everjfc- way. My memory was clear. I was quitela new woman in a few weeks after taking Dr Williams' Pink Pills, never really tired, blessed with a healthy appetite, and able to sleep well at night In my opinion Dr. Williams' Pink Pills build up the brain as well as the body, blood and nerves." When the Blood becomes thin and weak the system rapidly breaks down. Dr. Williams' Pink Pills for Pale People make Good, Rich Blood and feed the starved nerves. They hare cured Aniemia, General Weakness, Influenza's After-Effects Indigestion, Eczema, Rheuma- tism, Sciatica, St Vitas' Dance, Nervous Disorders, Paralysis and Ixtdies' Ailments. Sold by all dealers, but insist on having the genuine pills, for substitutes never cure. Sold by all chemists and druggists at P.T. 18 the box and P.T. 70 for six boxes.
